pages:
STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 26, 2025
Sylvia Blythe
Mission Ranch
9300 Lahring Road,
Gaines, MI, 48436
Re: License #: CI250410439
SI #: 2025SIC0000863
Dear Ms. Blythe:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan must be completed and routed in CWLM. If you desire technical assistance in
addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the WOC area manager Shay Mavis at 269-243-2725.
Sincerely,
Stephanie S Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000863
Special Investigation Intake Date: July 18, 2025
License #: CI250410439
Licensee Group Organization: Prism Project
Licensee Designee: Angelee Palmore
Chief Administrator: Sylvia Blythe
Agency Name: Mission Ranch
Agency Address: 9300 Lahring Road
Gaines, MI 48436
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 06/10/2027
Capacity: 6
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
7/21/2025 Video Conference Special Investigation Initiation
7/23/2025 Face to Face Documentation received or sent;
Unannounced Visit; Special
Investigation Initiation; Interview
7/23/2025 Email Documentation received or sent
7/23/2025 Email Incident Notification
7/25/2025 Email Documentation received or sent
7/25/2025 Email Documentation received or sent
7/28/2025 Email Documentation received or sent
7/29/2025 Email Documentation received or sent
8/11/2025 Phone Interview
8/20/2025 Email Documentation received or sent
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4104 Rules compliance
Section (2) After being licensed, an institution shall, on an ongoing basis,
Description comply with the act, child caring institution rules, and terms of the
license.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The youth at the facility are sleeping in a converted garage space.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Youth A was not very talkative but did report sleeping in a
bedroom and never in a garage.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Youth B said she has never slept in a garage, stating she
has her own bedroom.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Staff 1 said the youth only sleep in the designated rooms,
and said she has never seen anyone sleep in a garage.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Staff 2 said the youth sleep in bedrooms, and she has never
seen or heard of them sleeping in the garage.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on August 11, 2025.
Staff 3 said each youth has their own bedroom and have never
been made to sleep in a garage.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July
23, 2025. Supervisor said the youth only sleep in bedrooms and
have never slept in garage space.
Program Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on July 23, 2025. Program Director said the youth are never
made to sleep in a garage. Program Director said the garage
space was renovated into two bedrooms prior to the opening of
the facility and there is no other garage.
Residential Director was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on July 23, 2025. Residential Director said the youth each
have their own bedroom and are never forced to sleep in any
garage space.
2

Tour Observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on July 23, 2025. The youth’s
bedrooms were observed. Youth have their own bedrooms and
there are six total rooms, four down one hallway and two down
another hallway. The hallway with the two bedrooms was
previously an attached garage, however, it has been converted
into appropriate bedrooms and there is no longer garage space.
Documents Reviewed:
• Mission Ranch Original Inspection report was reviewed.
The report is dated December 12, 2022, and includes a
description of the home with six bedrooms. The Fire
Inspection was completed on July 21, 2022, and had an A
rating.
• Mission Ranch Renewal Inspection dated May 20, 2025,
was reviewed. The Fire Inspection was completed on
March 19, 2025, with an A rating.
• The Mission Ranch facility files were reviewed in the
CWLM system and did not indicate any change in licensing
capacity or amendments to the original licensing study to
indicate a change in structure of the building.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per review of the facility
files, interviews, and a tour the youth are not sleeping in a garage,
and the bedrooms were converted from a garage prior to opening
and the fire inspections have deemed them safe and appropriate.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The youth in the facility are not receiving treatment services.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Youth A was not very talkative but reported getting therapy
and being able to go out in the community to do activities as well
as playing outside at the facility on the swing set and with the
animals.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Youth B said she goes to individual counseling twice a week
3

at Creekside Services. Youth B said she does not have group
therapy. Youth B said the staff offer outings and activities
throughout the week. Youth B said staff are not helping her to
learn how to do anything on her own, noting she already knew
how to cook, clean, and do her own laundry when she was placed.
Youth B denied getting any life skills classes or groups. Youth B
said she wants to build a resume and learn budgeting and staff
are not assisting her.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Staff 1 said the youth are provided with individual therapy
twice per week, and group therapy if needed. Staff 1 said the
youth are given weekly packets to complete with their goals,
affirmation statements, and coping strategies. Staff 1 said staff are
provided weekly updates from the administration team for each
youth, and this information is both emailed to each staff and
placed in the communication binder in the staff area for review.
Staff 1 said the youth are given education year round through
Second Street Learning, which is online as well as a teacher
coming to the facility weekly to work with the youth. Staff 1 said
the youth are given a variety of activities throughout the day
including working out in the gym, gardening, interacting with the
animals, playing outdoors on the tennis court, basketball court, or
swings. Staff 1 said there is also a weekly outing schedule for the
youth including going to the movies, beach, or park. Staff 1 said
the youth are provided with Life Skills opportunities including meal
planning with a volunteer, cooking, cleaning, and budgeting. Staff
1 said there are many opportunities each day for the youth to
participate in regarding their treatment plan and fun activities.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Staff 2 said the youth are provided with therapy twice a
week. Staff 2 said they are provided with many outings and
activities throughout the week however they are not mandatory
and at times youth will decide not to participate. Staff 2 said the
youth are provided with education year round and do their work
online with education staff. Staff 2 said the youth are given life
skills programming that includes learning how to do laundry, cook
a meal, clean appropriately, and budget their allowance. Staff 2
said she feels there is ample programming opportunity for the
youth at Mission Ranch.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on August 11, 2025.
Staff 3 said the youth are provided with online summer school
Monday through Thursday each week. Staff 3 said there is a
doctor that comes to the facility once per month and sees the
4

youth. Staff 3 said the youth go to individual therapy twice each
week. Staff 3 said there are many other activities planned for the
youth throughout the week called “balanced living” where the
youth have chores and get paid, also they are getting paid to
attend school. Staff 3 said the money is added to a “green light
card” and the staff give each youth their card during outing for
them to spend their money. Staff 3 said direct care staff help youth
cook, clean, and do laundry. Staff 3 said she feels there are many
programming aspects for youth to participate in should they chose
to.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July
23, 2025. Supervisor said the youth are provided with individual
counseling twice per week. Supervisor said there is a weekly care
team meeting that reviews each youth and their goals. Supervisor
said the meeting minutes are shared with the direct care staff via
email and posted in the staff communication log so that staff are
up to date on treatment goals for each youth. Supervisor said the
youth are enrolled in summer school through Second Street
Learning which is online Monday through Thursdays and is also
given educational supports by staff and a teacher that comes to
the facility weekly. Supervisor said life skills is incorporated into
daily programming that includes meal planning, cleaning, cooking,
and earning money. Supervisor said the youth are also offered a
group on Wednesdays that has a specific independent living
curriculum which is led by Program Director and Educational
Specialist.
Program Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on July 23, 2025. Program Director said Mission Ranch operates
under five main tiers including Spiritual Care, Education, Medical,
Life Skills, and Mental Health services for the youth. Program
Director said Spiritual Care is youth and parent driven, where the
youth identify their spiritual preference and the staff work to
accommodate the practices of that religion.
Program Director said Education is provided year-round through
Second Street Schools. Program Director said the school is virtual
through Ingenuity Program Director said the youth have an
educational specialist, paraeducator, tutor, and teacher that assist
them with their classes. Program Director said the facility also has
additional educational field trips planned for the youth throughout
the year including trips to the library, and museums.
Program Director said medical services are provided by Doctor
once per month at the facility. Program Director said the Director
addresses medical needs in between Doctor’s visits due to her
5

being a registered nurse. Program Director said the youth can
request medical services at any time and for anything they want.
Program Director said life skills are offered to the youth in several
ways. Program Director said the facility has a volunteer that
comes into the facility and does menu planning with the youth,
which also addresses nutrition. Program Director said the staff
offer to teach the youth to cook if they do not know how or if they
would like to gain additional experience. Program Director said the
staff will teach the youth how to properly clean and do laundry.
Program Director said she has a life skills curriculum that is
offered to the youth weekly in a group setting which covers self-
care, volunteering, resume building, and money management.
Program Director said each youth is given a “green light card” and
money is loaded onto the card for them to spend on outings,
however they must save a portion of the money each week as part
of money management. Program Director said each youth is given
a weekly allowance and given other opportunities to earn money
throughout the week.
Program Director said the youth are provided individual
counseling twice per week at Creekside Counseling. Program
Director said that Residential Director will communicate with the
therapists and make sure information is passed onto them as
necessary as well as obtaining information for the youth treatment
plans and service plans. Program Director said after connecting
with the therapists Residential Director brings weekly updates for
each youth to the Care Team Meeting each Monday. Program
Director said this information is shared via email and a hardcopy is
placed in the communication log with all direct care staff, so they
are up to date on each youth’s goals. Program Director said
monthly medication reviews are also completed at Creekside
Counseling for each youth.
Program Director said she also develops a central calendar with
many planned activities for the youth to participate in each week.
Program Director said these activities can include things like going
to the beach, movies, parks, out to eat, and shopping. Program
Director said they cannot force the youth to participate in the
programming offered but they do their best to encourage them to
participate.
Residential Director was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on July 23, 2025. Residential Director said the youth are
provided individual counseling twice per week at Creekside
Counseling. Residential Director said she is in contact with the
therapist and will provide information for therapy and get
information for the youth’s treatment goals. Residential Director
said the information from the therapist is discussed in the weekly
6

care team meetings and those minutes are provided to direct care
staff by Supervisor. Residential Director said the youth’s individual
service plans and updated service plans along with treatment
plans are also available for staff to read. Residential Director said
the youth are enrolled in Second Street Learning for summer
school which is online, and the Educational Specialist assists
youth with any support they need. Residential Director said life
skills are being provided by some of the staff, however is optional
for the youth to participate in.
Documents Reviewed:
• Care Team Meeting Minutes from June 9, 2025, June 16,
2025, June 23, 2025, and July 7, 2025, were reviewed. The
minutes thoroughly review each youth in the program
noting weekly appointments, strengths, challenges, therapy
progress and goals, education update, life skills
participation and goals, medical updates/concerns, spiritual
care goals/needs, service plan review, safety interventions,
and programming updates.
• Resident Calendar for the month of June 2025, with
detailed appointments and activities for the youth. The
calendar included things such as medical appointments,
court hearing, church services, baking class, menu
planning, gardening times, therapy, medication reviews,
and other fun outings.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews and documentation review it is determined the youth
are provided with programming that addresses youth’s needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The staffing at the facility is not sufficient to meet the needs of the
youth.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Youth A was not very talkative but reported feeling safe and
that there was always two staff working when she is awake.
7

Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Youth B said she has been placed there since February 28,
2025, and there are typically four youth in the program with two or
three staff working with them each day. Youth B said some staff
“know how to work with us” while others “are scared of the kids
and let them do whatever they want”. Youth B said she knows the
staff are scared of the youth because they will tell them to do
something and when the youth refuses the staff will not “push it” or
“even try to talk to them” they just “let it go”. Youth B said she will
also see staff “avoid talking” to youth about “certain issues” that
might make them upset.
Youth B said about a week ago her, Youth C, and Youth D were in
the dining room area talking about how they did not want to be in
the program anymore. Youth B said Staff 3 opened the closet door
and Youth C pushed past her and stole the van keys and ran out
the sliding door in the dining room. Youth B said Staff 3 just “stood
there in shock” and she and Youth D ran out of the slider door
over to the van. Youth B said Youth C said she knew how to drive
and so was in the driver's seat while she and Youth D were
passengers. Youth B said “[Youth C] was lying and did not know
how to drive” and hit the house about four times in a row, then
placed it in reverse and drove backwards quickly getting stuck in a
big mud puddle and so she Youth C, and Youth D jumped out of
the van and walked. Youth B said Staff 3 and Supervisor never
came out of the house to stop them. Youth B said she, Youth C,
and Youth D got about three miles away before the police brought
them back to the facility. Youth B said once back at the facility
Youth C ended up going with the police to the hospital while she
and Youth D were given some food and allowed to watch
television before going to bed. Youth B said the following Monday
she and Youth D decided to run away again and walked out of the
house with staff following them until the end of the driveway and
they kept walking, but staff stopped. Youth B said she and Youth D
made it to Detroit and “hung out for five days” and then she
decided to come back. Youth B said Youth D continues to be
AWOL.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Staff 1 said the ratio for Mission Ranch is one staff to three
youth, and the facility only takes four total youth. Staff 1 said there
are always at least two staff working each shift and normally more
staff on shift or at the facility. Staff 1 said she has felt confident
handling any crisis situation that has arisen on her shift, noting
she has only called the police one time due to a youth AWOL.
Staff 1 said she has been trained in Crisis Prevention Institute
8

however has never had to restrain a youth and has only utilized
the de-escalation portion of the model. Staff 1 said when present
with aggressive behaviors the staff can usually talk the youth
down, separate them from the group and process the issues with
them.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July 23,
2025. Staff 2 said Mission Ranch ratio is one staff to three youth
and they take up to four youth at a time. Staff 2 said there is
always at least two staff working each shift and many times it is
three or more in the facility. Staff 2 said she feels the training was
very detailed and taught her how to engage with the youth in all
circumstances. Staff 2 said she has not been trained in Crisis
Prevention Institute yet and does not participate in any restraints.
Staff 2 said she has never had to call the police for assistance.
Staff 2 said the administration team communicates very well and
the staff are provided many tools on how to work with the youth
and what their individual goals are. Staff 2 said there are meetings
twice a month for staff where they review the youth and address
questions or concerns the staff have regarding the youth or
program. Staff 2 said the youth’s treatment goals are provided to
staff weekly both via email and in the staff communication
logbook.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on August 11, 2025.
Staff 3 said she was provided with many trainings to prepare her
for her job and feels confident in her work. Staff 3 denied seeing
any staff intimidated by the youth or not holding them accountable
to the program expectations. Staff 3 said there are times staff
have a lack of assertiveness due to being unsure of the program
rules.
Staff 3 said she was working with Supervisor on July 12, 2025.
Staff 3 said in the evening Youth C grabbed the phone and was
trying to make calls when she was not allowed to, so she took the
phone and locked it in the staff closet. Staff 3 said Supervisor was
in the living area with Youth A and she was with Youth B and Youth
D while Youth C was in the kitchen and dining area. Staff 3 said
she and Supervisor went into the staff area around 10:30pm and
saw the door frame was popped away from the wall a bit however
the door is hard to shut at times and so did not think much of it.
Staff 3 said Supervisor was trying to put the trim back flush to the
wall when Youth C pushed by them, got into the staff closet briefly,
and then ran out of the sliding glass doors in the dining room.
Staff 3 said she and Supervisor thought Youth C had grabbed the
phone due to her behavior earlier that evening. Staff 3 said she
set down her computer and began to follow Youth C while
9

Supervisor went to shut off the alarm that went off from the slider
door opening. Staff 3 said as she was about to walk out the slider
doors, Supervisor said the phone does not work outside, and
since Youth C has a history of walking around outside and then
coming back in after a few minutes she decided to let her have a
little space. Staff 3 said Supervisor then yelled “she has the van
keys” and Youth B and Youth D ran out the slider glass door and
she followed them. Staff 3 said she told Youth B and Youth D not
to get in the van and to make good choices, however they did not
listen and got in the van. Staff 3 said the van then began to move
so she ran back inside so she did not get hit. Staff 3 said she sat
near Youth A in the house while Supervisor called the police. Staff
3 said Youth C drove the van into the facility twice and then she
saw one of the other youth switch and get into the driver’s seat
and reversed the van quickly into a muddy area of the yard and
got it stuck. Staff 3 said all three youth jumped out of the van and
began to run. Staff 3 said once the youth ran away from the van,
she and Supervisor took Youth A into the basement because they
were unsure if the youth would come back and drive the van into
the facility again. Staff 3 said the maintenance staff arrived and
had the keys from the van. Staff 3 said the police arrived about
11pm and took the information about the youth and the van
incident. Staff 3 said the police found the youth and returned them
to the facility around 12:30am Staff 3 said she did not feel there
was anything she could have done differently in the incident.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on July
23, 2025. Supervisor said the facility ratio is one staff for three
youth. Supervisor said they always have two staff working each
shift and try to have a third but that is not always possible.
Supervisor said the staff are all provided a thorough onboarding
training to prepare staff for job expectations. Supervisor said she
conducts two staff meetings per month, one that she prepares with
specific information and the second that is more of a
question/answer session for staff to ask any questions they have
or to discuss things that are currently going on in the facility.
Supervisor said she is conducting one on one meetings with each
staff every other month to check in and review their strengths and
needs. Supervisor said overall the staff are provided with the
information needed for the job, however have a difficult time
remembering the rules and enforcing them on the floor with the
youth. Supervisor said there have been a few youth placed that
the staff are afraid of and therefore will avoid interacting with them
or will not hold them accountable to the rules.
10

Supervisor said she was working with Staff 3 on July 12, 2025.
Supervisor said throughout the day Youth C seemed to be more
escalated when she was interacting with her, so she had removed
herself from the dining room and was working with Youth A in the
other room. Supervisor said Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D were
all sitting in the dining room and Staff 3 was nearby supervising.
Supervisor said once it was bedtime she went to the staff area to
put the tablet in the closet and noticed the trim around the door
had been pulled away from the wall, so she opened the door and
tried to pop the trim back in place. Supervisor said Youth C made
a comment about being the one that pulled the trim off the wall but
then walked away and was talking to Youth B and Youth D.
Supervisor said she began placing the tablet in the closet when
she heard Staff 3 say “you cannot be back there” and when she
turned around to see what Staff 3 was talking about Youth C
pushed past her and got into the closet quickly and then ran
outside through the sliding glass doors. Supervisor said she
thought Youth C had taken the cordless phone which does not
work outside. However, she looked outside and saw Youth C in
the facility van and then saw her run van into the house.
Supervisor said she immediately called 911. Supervisor said Youth
B and Youth D ran outside and got into the van with Youth C.
Supervisor said Youth C drove the van into the house about four
times, so she took Youth A and Staff 3 and went downstairs for
safety because she was worried Youth C was going to drive the
car into the kitchen or entryway which is where they were located.
Supervisor said the maintenance staff came over to the facility and
told her that the facility van was stuck in the mud and the youth
were gone. Supervisor said she made the notification calls until
the police arrived. Supervisor said she gave the police a full report
with all the youths information and about an hour and a half later
they returned with Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D. Supervisor said
Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D were very escalated and Youth C
ended up going by ambulance to the hospital for an evaluation.
Supervisor said she allowed Youth B and Youth D to speak to their
families and then let them watch television to relax before they
went to bed. Supervisor said the police have been contacted more
often recently due to Youth C and her aggressive behavior.
Program Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on July 23, 2025. Program Director said the contract ratio is one
staff to three youth, noting the schedule always has at least two
staff and most times three staff, additionally during the weekdays
there are many other administrative staff present onsite. Program
Director said there is one direct care supervisor that supervises all
direct care staff. Program Director said staff take turns being “lead
11

staff” on each shift however this person does not provide
mentoring or supervision to the direct care staff. Program Director
said staff are currently trained in Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI)
as their behavior management model. Program Director said a
former staff comes into the facility to provide this training yearly,
noting new staff are usually trained within the first six months of
hire. Program Director said new staff all participate in Six Core
Strategies upon hire, however there is no ongoing or retraining in
the model once hired. Program Director said staff are all trained
annually in Trust Based Relational Intervention training which
focuses on building relationships with the youth and de-escalation
techniques. Program Director said staff meetings are held virtually
twice per month for staff to ask questions or Supervisor to review
any areas of need with the staff. Program Director said there are
many helpful and information trainings staff attend, however there
are times when it seems there is a disconnect from what they are
trained and what they can put into practice with the youth.
Program Director said staff can call the police if they feel situations
arise to that level, or if they are uncertain, they can call the on-call
staff who will talk them through the decision on if police contact is
necessary. Program Manager said all calls to the police that she is
aware of were warranted.
Residential Director was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on July 23, 2025. Residential Director said the staff are all
provided onboarding, twice a month meeting, and additional
trainings each month. Residential Director said staff do not always
choose to attend trainings and they are not mandatory. Residential
Director said overall, staff lack experience in child welfare and
many struggle with youth that give any push back and are not able
to hold youth accountable. Residential Director said staff do not
know how to incorporate what training they have attended into
their day-to-day work. Residential Director said many of the staff
will treat the youth more like a friend and lack the ability to enforce
structure.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of July 12, 2025, kitchen, dining room, and
outside area was reviewed on July 28, 2025. The facility
provided several video clips of multiple areas in the house and
outside.
The camera footage of the dining room area showed Staff 3 and
Supervisor behind the counter in staff area, while Youth B, Youth
C, and Youth D were at the table. Youth C walks out of camera
view and comes back into view behind the counter in the staff
area, Staff 3 stands in front of Youth C and then they go out of the
12

camera view. Youth C comes back on camera running from behind
the staff area. Staff 3 and Supervisor come into camera view and
are staring at the direction Youth C ran. Youth B and Youth D get
up and walk into another room, out of camera view. Supervisor
walks off camera and comes back into view with a phone in her
hand walking through the dining room and out of camera view.
The kitchen camera has both video and audio. Youth C is seen
coming into the kitchen briefly and then goes out of camera view
after entering the staff area. A few moments later Youth C comes
into camera view and runs through the kitchen and out the sliding
glass doors. The alarm begins to sound, Staff 3 comes into
camera view from the staff area briefly with a computer in her
hand and then walks back into staff area and off camera. Youth A,
Youth B, Youth D, and Staff 3 come into kitchen and are standing
near counter, making statements about Youth C and where she
went. Staff 3 walks through the kitchen to the sliding glass doors
and shuts the door and then walks back to the counter where the
youth are standing. Supervisor briefly walks through the kitchen
holding her phone to her ear. Supervisor is heard yelling “she took
the van key”, Staff 3 walks out of the room in the same direction
as Supervisor had just left. Youth B and Youth D are heard saying
“I want to get out of here”, “you wanna”, “fuck it”, “bye love you
guys”, then leave out of the sliding glass door in the kitchen. Staff
3 walks through the kitchen and out the sliding glass doors saying,
“come on you guys”. Supervisor is heard saying, “they are running
the van into the house”, Staff 3 comes back inside and takes
Youth A out of the kitchen. Supervisor is standing in the kitchen on
her phone and red taillights are seen through the window.
Supervisor exits the kitchen as the van headlights are now seen
through the kitchen window.
The outdoor camera footage is very dark which makes it unable to
see the individuals that come out of the house and into the van.
The camera shows someone coming around the house and
getting into the driver’s side of the facility van. The van moves
forward and into the house, two additional individuals are seen
getting into the van, and the van moves forward again several
times into the house. An individual gets out of the back door and
the driver’s door and switch places, the van is then seen rapidly
accelerating backwards and to the left into the yard. The van does
not move and about two minutes later the van doors open and
individuals are seen running from the van.
Documents Reviewed:
• Mission Ranch Staff Schedules from June 23, 2025,
through July 20, 2025, were reviewed. The schedule has a
13

minimum of two staff working all shifts with some shifts
having more than two staff.
• MiSACWIS Incident Report dated July 12, 2025. The
incident report is consistent with Supervisor’s interview. The
Mission Ranch Critical Incident report dated July 12, 2025,
was reviewed and is identical to the MiSACWIS Incident
Report.
• Mission Ranch Behavior Management Policy was
reviewed. The policy indicates that staff are to respond to
disruptive behaviors using restorative practices designed to
foster dialogue about the reason, outcome, impact, and
improvement of the resident’s area(s) of growth.
• Mission Ranch Missing Person Plan was reviewed. The
procedure outlines the expectations of staff when a youth
elopes from the program and includes remaining calm and
interacting with the other youth in the home, informing other
staff of situation, calling the police, calling the on-call
administrator, calling the executive director, and making
required notifications. The policy does not require staff to
follow youth when they leave the program.
• Mission Ranch Ratio and Supervision Policy was reviewed.
The ratio is one staff to three youth for both waking and
sleeping hours. The expectation for staff to supervise youth
based on the history of the youth, service plan, and goals.
The staff are to ensure “Having knowledge of the residents’
whereabouts at all times is critical and is balanced with
allowing the residents a certain amount of privacy. As a
resident is able to be more responsible and dependable,
the supervision becomes less frequent or necessary. These
decisions are made on a case by case basis, by the
individual resident’s care team and with the safety of the
resident as the most important deciding factor.”
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per interviews with
Youth B, Supervisor, Program Director, and Residential Director,
the direct care staff working with the youth have shown
inconsistency with enforcing program expectation and rules with
youth that are difficult to manage, in addition they have had
difficulty taking what they have learned in trainings and meetings
and implementing the knowledge and skills while working with the
youth which has impacted the continual safety, protection, and
direct care and supervision of residents.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was provided to Mission Ranch in the
following areas:
14

• Provide CPI training for staff as part of onboarding.
• Provide additional CPI training to staff throughout the year
and not just at the annual refresher training. This could be
done in team meetings using specific behaviors that youth
are presenting with at the time.
• Incorporate additional BBI/Six Core Strategy information
into monthly meetings with staff. This information could be
directly related to what challenges the staff are facing and
ideas on how to rectify those challenges.
• Leadership work shifts alongside direct care staff to mentor
and support them and ensure they are confident in their
abilities to manage youth’s behaviors and run the program
as designed.
• When challenging youth are placed at the facility, it is
recommended a specific behavior plan is developed for the
youth for staff to follow that provides further guidance in
how to work with that youth successfully.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
